story:
WHO?

I’M WG.  I currently have the blessing of being a “musical nomad”. People and places all over the world are a continuous inspiration for my music. However, my main inspiration is from a promise I made to myself over 50 years ago. 

Here’s how that promise came about:  I was 16 when I began performing professionally.  Years later, I was on track for a great career when the draft interrupted my path and the music stopped. I don’t really know why I chose a safer career after I returned to regular life, but I did. Perhaps I listened to what everyone was telling me I must do.  Now I’m listening to myself. 

It took 50 years but now I am a musician again.    My compositions have now been featured in two International Jazz Day concerts with me performing them as well as numerous other events in Europe. 

 

WHAT IS THE PROJECT?

We are giving a gift that eases a stressful world.  This means we are giving my album, Seaside Daydreams, along with very effective stress-ease program developed by my wife, Lana, for free to EVERYONE in the world that wants it.

 

WHY?

When I made my promise five decades ago, I also committed to making a difference with my music. 

In my former high-pressure career, I, and almost everyone I knew, was constantly stressed.  Recalling how that affected me, I committed to develop an integrated approach to help others ease life in an over-stressed world.

My wife, Lana Sorrento is an author who helps people through her books, career and our non-profit foundation.  She has helped thousands therefore it was natural for her to contribute her Stress-Ease program to our project.

 

WHAT IS SEASIDE DAYDREAMS?

The video music demonstrates two of the songs we have already produced for the album. 

My heart is in all these songs as an inspiration to renewed dreams and peace in crazy times.

My Seaside Daydreams songs wrote themselves after 50 years of dreaming.  I hope these songs and my story re-awakens your dreams. 

I’m a jazz musician in heart and soul but, for this project I needed to compose in a style that specifically affected the listeners continuous degree of relaxation.  (See: What is the Style below)

 

WHAT DO WE NEED?

We need to finish recording five more songs and then master the album.  The Stress-Ease program is ready to go, but we have invested all we can in this project. If you believe in our project, and are not looking to benefit in any way except in your heart, we really need you to join with us and make this your dream also.

All aspects of the project are well-organized and the financial needs have been carefully defined and budgeted.   Let’s get to know one another, give this to the world, kick back a little and celebrate the dream in all of us. 

 

WHAT IS THE STYLE?

Whatever your definition of Seaside Daydream’s style is, that’s it.  When I compose and perform, it’s usually focused around the complexities of passion and compassion. 

Sound, like color, evokes emotions in all of us. When writing chord progressions and melodies, I try to think about what feelings I want to get across.  Actually, when I compose, it feels like I’m not doing it.  At times, the result surprises me.

My Seaside Daydreams compositions are a departure for me because they required me to include the science of perceptual auditory organization in order to affect the listeners degree of relaxation.  I struggled to use the science as a way to enhance the result without contaminating my own personal style and lyricism but, in the end, I think it came out well. 

Everyday musicians, may not understand the science behind the attributes of individual musical events, but intuitively we know it to be true.  Without using intellect, good musicians naturally use temporal structure, tonal hierarchy and rhythmic value to affect an efficient abstract representation of the various relationships to emotion.

 

WHAT ABOUT PERKS?

The “perk” for his project is the joy of giving.  This is a project which we believe appeals to people who are not looking to benefit in any way except in their heart.  Tee-shirts, posters and other things may quickly become distant memories but helping others can become part of us.

Donors will be the first to access the free album and Stress-Ease program.

story:
Overview

Inspired by Talking Heads music and their own

In the summer of 2013 a group of Portland, Oregon musicians got together around the love of Talking Heads music. Especially that of the epic 1984 concert film, Stop Making Sense, which they consider to be the most brilliant concert film of all time. They began to perform with a 7-piece lineup that was inspired by that particular movie and time period. “There was so much funkiness, movement, and excitement to the music in that movie and we just knew it would get people excited and feel fresh” says Lawrence Orleck, co-founder and singer in the band.

Audiences keep coming back to see LDW. Not only for their exuberant interpretations of the legendary Talking Heads, but also for their original music, improvisation, choreography and the random experiences they deliver at every one of their shows. In a matter of 2 years they were playing to sold out shows all over the west coast and found themselves with the question: “What’s next?”

The upcoming Album – Movement in a spirited manner

For LDW, every performance matters, and, it’s that mantra, that has the band in the studio recording their first album, Movement in a spirited manner. “We were so inspired by playing David Byrne’s music for 3 years that we found ourselves in the studio writing this album and it just naturally fit into our set. That’s our evolution and trajectory. But, yes, we still play a ton of talking heads because, plain and simple, it’s fun. We named it Movement in a spirited manner because for the last 3 years we have been enthralled with the excitement and motion of our fans. They get down, big time.” Lawrence muses.

About the Album:

This is our first full-length record! The album will have 10 songs, including a nod to a classic Talking Heads tune...no, we won't tell you which one just yet!
 

The Collaborators:


Producers:  Paul Chandler, Steveland Swatkins, Anthony Resta
Musicians: Lawrence Orleck, Jessa Campbell, Taylor Stapleton, Hayley Dolan, Chuck Warda, Paul Chandler, Steveland Swatkins, Tyrone Hendrix, Joshua Simon
Mix Engineer: Justin Phelps, Karyadi Sutedja
 

What We Need & What You Get

Your Support. As a completely independent with a small team, (completely funded by ourselves), the only way we continue going is by our own work, and you, our incredible fans. It would literally be impossible without your help.
We need about $30,000 to make the recordings, the rewards & to pay all of the super talented and deserving musicians. We are hoping to raise a portion of that here.
I know, I know. The number seems big, but we tried to cut our costs as much as possible without sacrificing the quality of music you deserve. We are working hard, and working smart! 

There are tons of cool perks. Some of them are going to be exclusive to Indie-Gogo.
Which means, you will have what no one else does as a major thank you for making this happen.
And as an extra thank you, once we hit 50% funding we are going to be sharing the lyrics to Ebb & Flow, the original track featured in the video. 

If we don't reach the entire goal, it will take a bit longer to put out the album, but we will continue investing into this project until it's completed! This isn't a Road to Nowhere!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.  We'd love for you to share this campaign with others who may be interested! Follow us on social media and watch for our next show. 

Dance on.

Overview
Inspired by Talking Heads music and their own
In the summer of 2013 a group of Portland, Oregon musicians got together around the love of Talking Heads music. Especially that of the epic 1984 concert film, Stop Making Sense, which they consider to be the most brilliant concert film of all time. They began to perform with a 7-piece lineup that was inspired by that particular movie and time period. “There was so much funkiness, movement, and excitement to the music in that movie and we just knew it would get people excited and feel fresh” says Lawrence Orleck, co-founder and singer in the band.
Audiences keep coming back to see LDW. Not only for their exuberant interpretations of the legendary Talking Heads, but also for their original music, improvisation, choreography and the random experiences they deliver at every one of their shows. In a matter of 2 years they were playing to sold out shows all over the west coast and found themselves with the question: “What’s next?”

story:
After years of research into Handel’s own facsimiles, Artistic Director Mark Bailey has re-constructed Handel’s earliest vision of Messiah—the vision that came straight from his fullest inspiration.

Handel composed the legendary oratorio, Messiah, in a wave creativity. Premiered in 1742 at the Great Music Hall in Dublin, Ireland, the American Baroque Orchestra and Singers bring the work to life in its very earliest conception for the 2016-2017 season.

The American Baroque Orchestra and Singers perform with the exuberance and artistry of Handel’s own musicianship, re-creating the composer’s original soundscapes through the instruments and vocal styles of the time.

With the fervor of inspiration, the American Baroque Orchestra and Singers is proud to present Handel’s Messiah in its original conception on authentic, period instruments for its 2016-2017 season.

Your contribution will go directly to the players' fees and basic operational expenses for our Messiah concerts for December 2016! Every donation, no matter how small, makes a huge difference toward meeting our Spring fundraising goal!

story:
The Quest 

Admiral Dawg just released the most epic video game rap album ever. So  naturally, it's time to peddle the music to our follow nerds in an interactive quest for glory. Not only the album, but the live side of the Dawg. The Admiral has been rappin all over Houston at open mics, but it's time to increase the stakes! It's time we book some unique spots/venues and upgrade the live set up with 2 wireless miss, a new P.A and some bomb speakers. And oh man... If we can raise enough gold, we're going to buy a friggin bus and create the nerdiest live show on wheels.

Equally important, it's time to feed the dragons and put some money into promoting the music. Brethren, join us in this worthy cause that will one day become a tale to tell your orc grandchildren.

Phat loots for phat loots

  • @ $500 - Promotion Money - The bread and butter of the campaign. We've launched the website, got the youtube/facebook channel poppin, got the album on Itunes/Spotify and it's time blow the foghorn. It's time to strategically spam cyberspace and expand! $500 would allow us to reach tens of thousands of gamers and nerds for months! 
  • @ $1,500 - Dawg Swag and Merch. Shirts, physical albums, bumper Stickers, ale mugs, and more loots. It's time to put in some bulk orders in and have an epic variety to sell at our live shows! The merchandise sales will also help The Admiral start paying his companions. Free it awesome and all, but it's time to do things properly!  
  • @ $2,500 - We'll be able to purchase touring quality wireless mics and upgrade our P.A equipment to make our shows exponentially better. Not only that, we'll be customizing our mics to be fit for a bard and ranger. Sword hilt microphone? Yes please!
  • @ $7,500 - The Admiral Dawg rap bus! So we looked into renting a party bus to play some mobile shows, but the logistics were super sketch.  Fear not lads! Turns out we can buy a capable bus, modify it to hell, and start performing on the go. Not only that, but shoot music video's, park it at house parties for epic shows. 

----------------------------------------------------------------

Trade!? 
Customize your perk game with a digital download of the album for $10 or
  • $10 perk - A digital copy of Brews, Weed, RPG's  in its full epic entirety
  • $15 perk - A dawg dog shirt for your pup!
  • $20 perk - THE SHRINE
  • $45 perk - HOODIE + ALBUM
  • $100 perk + Hella loot and a bag of potato chips. 

The Impact

The Admiral Dawg is not just about music, but also acts as a catalyst for fellow artists, gamers, and nerds alike. A successful push to get the name and music out there is the beginnings of a unique realm. Video games, D & D, music, beer... it's all art. Helping or donating to the campaign will unlock limitless potential!

The Grind

Thus far, we've maintained 100% independence and originality. Challenge? Hell yes - but there ain't a devious trickster in the forest that can take this from us. This is our first marketing push of many. Grind some XP and level up with us through the noob dungeons! 

Feed the Dragons!

Admiral Dawg and his companions saga has only just begun. Anyone can be a bard in our lands. Get out there and inspire the troops by sharing the Indiegogo campaign, facebook page, spotify/tunes, and more with your friends. Better yet, when we see you share any or all of the links we'll hook you up with a bumper sticker or draw a picture and send it to you!

Spotify - https://play.spotify.com/artist/5LNyuT0GTiolXdIh2ZWuYi

Admiral Dawg! - www.admiraldawg.com

Facebook Page - www.facebook.com/admiraldawg/

Youtube - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCOpp8KvHUKwsPxLvl8KmzIQ

story:
All Perks come with a Digital Download!

*UPDATE: WE HAVE EARNED ENOUGH TO PRINT CD'S AND MERCHANDISE! Please ignore any perks that state otherwise as we are unable to edit them.*

HUNG was started as a hobby/project. However, after our first two albums it became clear that other like-minded people were finding our music and enjoying what we do. HUNG has grown from one man's dream in his bedroom to a fully-fledged duet with one aim: to create something extraordinary.

Both of us in HUNG make music that takes influence from the modern progressive metal scene but also blend a variety of genres and techniques together to create something inspiring, unique and overall different.

Our newest album encompasses all these traits and expands on everything we've done up to date.
It is a 14-track album that merges genres such as (but not limited to) rap, rock, electronic, classical, jazz etc.

On top of that we have some truly AMAZING guest features recorded, Angel Vivaldi, Jake Lowe and Stephen Taranto from The Helix Nebula, Andrew Patterson from Cortexiphan, Dan Sugarman (previously As Blood Runs Black) and Matt Jones from Dakesis. 

The physical copies are being released as dual disc sets with one being instrumental and one being original with vocals. The instrumental copy will also be available for download.

Nothing makes us happier than sharing our vision with the world and receiving support for what we do. It is because of this loyal support that we have decided to make our upcoming release both digital and physical.

However! WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Both members of HUNG work full time and have had to take time off work to create DJURASSIC WORD. We are lucky enough to be sponsored by Crossfade Productions, therefore all recording and graphic design is free of charge... But printing, mastering and marketing costs are why this project has been created.

Without funding, the album will be released as a downloadable copy, we will have no merch for sale, no hard copies and no funds for marketing.

The demand we've received for both merch and physical CD's encouraged us to create an indiegogo campaign to help us to afford the printing and to supply our supporters.

DJURASSIC WORD releases on the 1st August 2016 and we would absolutely LOVE it if you could be a part of its prehistoric journey. 

Thank you to anyone who contributes.

 

Where are your funds going?

  • Physical CDs
  • T-shirt printing
  • Mastering
  • Marketing

These are the 4 essential things we are using the funding for.
HUNG is a non profit artist, meaning that we recycle everything we earn into the band, if we raise more money than we need, the surplus will remain with HUNG and be used to market future releases and print merchandise.

(Please accept our deepest apologies for the stupidly high prices of shipping outside the EU, we have tried to get the cost to a minimum but it is still ludicrous. As a show of good faith we will package every posted item with extra special care.)

The Impact

"With some more promotion and hard work, HUNG will swing its presumably massive, artistically-sound wang into the faces of lucky metal fans across the globe." - I Probably Hate Your Band

"HUNG is a stunning example of the DIY world as they do all their own recording, producing, advertising, and album artwork. In a short time HUNG has been able to gain fans from all over the globe simply by having great music and working diligently and intelligently." - Wordkrapht

"Don’t even hesitate in getting HUNG’s self-titled album, or their two previous albums before this. It brings to light completely original and daring music in an otherwise easy-to-compare genre where many sound the same." - ItDjents

Every review we have had online has been incredibly gracious and complimentary. We feel honoured to have such respected individuals speaking so highly of us.

We spend so long working on our music, it seems a shame to be limited to such a small circle of enthusiasts, granted that small circle is delightful, but we would LOVE to expand our reach.

We have never missed an album release date; each album we release evolves and improves; every review we've had has been both flattering and laudatory.

We will deliver.

DJURASSIC WORD is our best album to date. We have crafted something that redefines the modern progressive metal scene and challenges the trends.

Your contribution will amplify DJURASSIC WORD and allow us to reach more people who enjoy our creations.

Sources: 
http://iprobablyhateyourband.com/all-reviews/hung-hung/

http://wordkrapht.com/main/2015/10/05/hung-self-titled/

http://www.itdjents.com/reviews-2/hung-self-titled-album-review-pending-editingapproval/

Risks & Challenges

The main risk would be not having enough money to market DJURASSIC WORD, which is something we would have to face head on, the contributors come first and production of hard copies/T-shirts is the primary reason we have started this campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some of you may not be able to donate, for whatever reason, however you can still help!
Just sharing this campaign on your social media or with a friend who enjoys progressive music could help us reach our goal.

The album will be free to download from our website (pay what you want) and you will still have access to our music.

Your efforts are valued!

Website: http://www.iamhung.bandcamp.com
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/hungofficial
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/crossfadeproductions

story:
Summary

My name is Jason Benson and I'm a musician, a singer/songwriter, producer, and owner of The Sound Studio (thesound-studio.com) recording studio located in Casper, Wyoming. I come from several generations of musicians and have been playing, writing, and recording music for over 15 years. I believe music connects our lives in a unique way like nothing else can. It is my desire to impact people's lives not just through my music, but by capturing the music of others through recording.

The purpose of this fundraiser is to travel to Nashville, Tennessee to record a 5-6 song record of original songs with a veteran producer and engineer. Not only will this project give me experience in working with other seasoned musicians on my record, but it will also help my skills in the area of producing other artists through my own studio. 

Below is a list of the cost involved in creating this project. Your contribution will not only affect this project but many others that springboard from this. Would you please join me by supporting this endeavor?


Fundraiser Goal: $12,800


Recording Production 

Cost: ($1400/Song Average): $7000 

Production includes (this does not include product cost): 

  • Charting
  • Musicians
  • Studio rental
  • Mixing

***Product Cost:

Cost: $1000 (New Cost $515)

 Product cost includes:

  • CDs with Jacket Ad full design
  • Digital distribution to all major digital media streams

Projected Travel:

Cost: $2800 

Estimated Airfare: $$400/per person

Estimated Hotel: $145/Night

Estimated Food: $59/Day

Estimated Rental Car: $400


***Video Production: 

I've decided to use GoPro's and stationary video recording to save on cost!

Cost: $500 (New Cost $0)

I will be bringing a video producer to film and photograph the events of the week. This will give memories of the project and also give an avenue for training when I return home. 


Fundraiser Perk Items: (Custom Studio Logo)

(New Cost $0.00) (The studio has graciously decided to donate these to my campaign!!)

Cost: $1000-1500 

  • T-shirt
  • Coffee Mug
  • Limited hand-pressed Vinyl records
  • 2 days at The Sound Studio in Casper, WY 
  • Other Perks through the campaign
Projected recording date is May 21st-28th

NEW Projected Recording date is JUNE 20th-27th


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to join in this project financially, please get the word out to everyone you know. You can use the links provided and post to your social media accounts!

Thank you all for joining in with this opportunity.

story:
The Skinny... 

For more than twenty-four years I have answered the call. I'm Tony Brown, and as a career Firefighter/Paramedic, I have been witness to many unpleasant events. Events that change peoples lives forever. I am proud to say that I've helped many people during those events. 

Now I am asking for your help. Help me achieve my dream of recording my first full length album of my original songs, titled "Small Town Big Heart."

I finally decided at the age of forty-nine to pursue this life long dream of mine. I bought my first guitar and began teaching myself to play. I had songs deep within me and wanted to get them out. I am now fifty-one, and in the two short years since picking up that guitar, I have recorded and released an EP of my first four songs. I have shared the studio and stage with such notables as Marty Stuart, Rudy Gatlin, Dale Watson, Red Simpson, Theresa Spanke, WS "Fluke" Holland, and others.

 I feel now is the time, and I am whole heartedly ready to answer this call.

I believe Country Music is in critical condition and in need of emergency attention. I believe I can help. My love for traditional Country Music runs very deep in my soul. 

My music fuses influences of traditional country, outlaw country, the Bakersfield sound, Texas country, west coast country rock, and gospel, to deliver a sound that is pure and honest. I believe fans of real country music will appreciate my songs, and my songwriting. 

I am a story teller, and that is one thing sorely missing in country music today. How big is your heart? Will you answer the call and help me get my music out there?


So Here's The Deal...

As an independent artist, I am on my own to make my dream a reality. I don't have the financial backing from music industry professionals or a record label. As such, it is up to me to get my music written, recorded, manufactured, marketed, and distributed. It is a daunting task indeed to have your music heard in today's music business climate. It takes a lot of money, time, and effort to make it happen.

But it is my dream, and I am in full pursuit.

Let me break it down for you in more detail:

  • Recording studios charge by the hour for their services to record and mix your songs. Generally speaking, a safe estimate for an independent artist is 3-4 hours per song at around $100 per hour.   
  • Session artists (professional musicians hired to play on your session) charge by the hour, the song, or by the instrument. I generally have 4-8 on each song. Average rate is around $150-$300 per instrument per song.
  • While I do have a couple of projects under my belt as a Producer, I have decided to bring in a fresh set of ears for this album. I am very fortunate to have the multi award winning Producer Milo Deering joining me on this album.
  •  Once the album is recorded, and mixed, it will need to be mastered. This is the process that really smooths out the sound files and prepares them for their final format of digital download, CD, and Vinyl. Each format requires it's own mastering. This step is generally around $1000-$2000 for a project this size.
  • Then there is the artwork! This step usually requires a professional photographer and an on location photo shoot. In addition the services of a quality graphic artist are required to design and format the Album/CD cover. Go ahead and budget $1500-$2000 for these services.
  • Next up...Replication! This is where your project really comes alive. Your digital files and artwork are now sent to a Replicator who prints and packages your Album. This cost is based on how fancy you want your packaging, and the number of copies you want printed..the more you print, the lower the cost per unit.  You're looking at around $1500- $3000 for an initial print.
  • Now you have to get your brand new record out so all of your adoring fans can purchase it. Distribution! You can spend a small fortune in this step. This is where the indie artist has to get really creative. Fortunately there are many online outlets available including online stores such as CDBaby, itunes, Apple music, etc. as well as a host of internet radio stations to potentially play and help sell your music. This step requires a lot of time, and effort to be successful. A budget of around $3000 for the initial start up here can help you go a long way in this step if you're willing to work it hard...I am!
  • All told I'm looking at an estimated cost for all of the above to be around $1500-$2000 per song, and  "Small Town Big Heart" is slated for thirteen songs.
  • My hope is to raise most, if not all of the needed funds through this campaign. Any shortages will come out of my pocket. I am determined to succeed.

The Bang For Your Buck...

The bottom line is I can't do this project without your help:

  • Now, I know there are a lot of wanna-be songwriters out there, and they all need help making their dreams come true. I truly believe I have written some really good songs, and I think they will stand on their own, and stand the test of time. My ultimate goal is to shop some of these songs around to the big boys in country music and get them to record them on their projects.
  • I have spent the past fifteen years of my life involved in the music business as more or less a hobby. I have produced and promoted just under two hundred shows, from small house shows, to large outdoor festivals. I have worked as a producer on my first record, and co-produced an album for Bakersfield Recording artist, Theresa Spanke. I have become well versed in the world of music, and I'm ready to make my mark as not only a successful promoter/producer, but as a multi genre singer/songwriter. 

What I'm Up Against...

I have eluded to the fact that I'm not a spring chicken. I'm also not afraid of a challenge. That being said, there are some harsh realities for a person such as myself trying to break into a new, highly fortified world.

  • Today's music business gatekeepers say I have to be young and beautiful in order to be successful in their world...I don't buy into that.
  • They say they know what YOU and I as music lovers want. Judging by most of what I hear of their choices today...I don't buy into that.
  • They say the era of music with meaningful stories is dead and gone...I don't buy into that.
  • They say I can't be a part of their world unless they control me...I don't buy into that.
  • If any of what you have read here rings true to you, then I need you to buy into me!

Times Are Tough All Over...

Hey I understand. Money is tight for a lot of us, and if you can't contribute right now...don't sweat it. You can still help me out tremendously:

  • You can simply make a little noise about me and my dream and campaign by sharing me on your social media outlets. There are tools here on Indiegogo that are available for you to help.
  • If you see me playing a show somewhere, stop by and say hello, maybe buy a CD or a t-shirt or something!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hello. We are What's My Line? An alternative rock band from the Midlands, UK. 

Recently, we have been going through a rough patch during our time as a band, given false hope etc. However, just as things were looking up, during February 14th, whilst on the way to a photoshoot, we were involved in a car accident. 

Thankfully, nobody was injured and we are all doing fine. However, due to this accident we now have to work together and pay off a lot of money to get things sorted, meaning paying extra to travel to practice and shows too, hindering the release and recording of our second Ep, "The Butterfly Effect." 

So, now we have turned to the most important people in our life for help. This is something we never wished to have to do as a band, we always wanted to work through it ourselves. But, with the things we now need to pay, unfortantely we cannot afford to record our second EP without your help. 

We will have this running for around 2 months if possible to try and raise as much funds for this EP as we possibly can. We hate asking for you to donate as we understand there are so many different charities out there and deserve the money so much more, but we'd forever be grateful for your help, as we do not want our time as a band to be cut short.

We can say from the bottom of our hearts, we would appreciate any donation or the sharing of this page more than anything in the world. You guys have given us so much already so we feel awful for asking for anything more. 

Again, Thank you so much for taking the time to read/share/donate for us. You have all been incredible and we cannot create this EP without you!
We are excited to move on and are excited to step into the future and see what it has to offer.

We love you guys,
What's My Line?

story:
"New Moon" is my first-ever album of music -  all original songs on the ukelele, which debuts with my book of poetry -  "Offering" - a collection of 22 poems in the tradition of mystic poetry as popularized by Hafiz, Rumi and Mirabhai.   As any Pooja Prema project, this one is mutli-media - including writing, music, visual art, and performance.  "Offering" will be hand-bound, with hand-printed/ stamped covers, and the "New Moon" covers feature gorgeous handprinted Monotypes (see photos below).  Both the CD and the book will be produced as limited edition runs of 250 each.  I will launch both projects with two live performances on April 29th and May 1st. 

Making art is a massive work, and I believe the world is renewed by more poetry and music with Heart.  In donating/ pre-buying these works (for a little more than retail), you are keeping the beautiful cycle of giving and receiving flowing - from you to me - into these offerings - and to the great big world.  As the song (Season's Swell)  says in the video "Love itself is something that must be spent - a currency that's liquid in your hands."   I am so excited to birth these babies into the world, and have been gestating them for 4 years now!  They are just about finished but, I need  a little moola to cover basic production expenses: 

*Muddy Angel Recording Studio

*Monotype printing, stamping and Book binding help from MVB printmaker

*Book printing cost from local printer Kwik Print

*Gratitude payment for musicians on the album
(Maya Mortman, Ryder Cooley, Francis Morris, Jonathan Talbot)

It is my hope that you will be 'enchanted' - both by the modern mystic poems, as well as by the songs; feel lifted and opened by them, and inspired to contribute to the their creation.   

More poems can be found here: http://www.poojaprema.com/poems.html

I will be uploading more song bites onto here as we finish mixing over the next couple of weeks: https://soundcloud.com/stream


Thank you so much for your love and support!

Pooja Prema

Video by Krysia Kurzyca/ Photo of Pooja by Janine Strong


Inheritance


Know this my love:

Our shared heart is at least as old as the Earth itself.

And the medicine you need 

is imbedded in every fiber of the universe. 

Earth medicine.

Earth technologies...

a stone, a feather, a flower, a leaf, a seed

water, fire

the sun dancing in the forest

nightime, and all the creaturas.

There is no thing in this world that is not 

an Instrument of Magic.

How will you then remember

the Heritage of one who is born on the Earth?

The Inheritance of one who is willing

to call this place Home?

story:
Update: I'm excited to announce that a 4th orchestra is now on board the project as part of the consortium: The Sage City Symphony from Bennington, VT!  I'm thrilled to have them on board the project as the first orchestra from Vermont!


The Project

During the Summer of 2016, I will finally fulfill a lifelong dream of mine by hiking the New England portion of the Appalachian Trail, a journey of more than 700 miles (about one-third of the entire 2,200 mile trail.)  I grew up in Massachusetts and spent many weekends exploring the woods and wilderness of this region.  Then I will spend the next year realizing another long-held dream of mine, to write my first symphony for orchestra, which will be a 20-25 minute symphony inspired by the experiences hiking the trail, commissioned by a consortium of orchestras across New England for the 80th anniversary of the completion of the trail.  The work will be in five movements, one for each New England state the trail passes through (Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine) with the music for each arising from my experiences hiking in that particular state.  Professional, community, and collegiate orchestras from these five New England states will each premiere the work in their own communities during the 2017-18 season.  Orchestras already on board include the Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra (Milford, MA), the Wellesley Symphony Orchestra in (Wellesley, MA), and the Wesleyan University Orchestra in (Middletown, CT).  Several more orchestras are interested, and we expect these ensembles to join the consortium within the next year.

We are also partnering with the Appalachian Trail Conservancy who is planning to have an orchestra from Maine perform the work as the main entertainment feature at their next Biennial Conference (August 4-10, 2017) at Colby College in Waterville, Maine, co-sponsored by the Appalachian Mountain Club and the Maine Appalachian Trail Club. 

Impact

But this project is more than just a realization of my own dreams and goals, and I am a firm believer that music can be a catalyst for positive change in the world.  Through these concerts throughout New England, associated educational events, and the publicity surrounding them, local orchestras will connect with the environmentalists and nature enthusiasts in their communities, a population that is not traditionally associated with classical music, in addition to their usual audiences. Likewise, this project will inspire and encourage classical music fans throughout the region to enjoy their local wilderness, including the Appalachian Trail, and to support local conservation efforts.

We invite you to be a part of the hike and donate to the project to help bring this musical celebration of the Appalachian Trail to life.  Every dollar helps!

Budget

Our goal is to raise at least half of the composer commission fee through this Indiegogo campaign.

Expenses ($22,000)

-$1,500: Estimated costs associated with doing the hike (including purchasing gear, fuel, food, and occasional lodging)

-$500: Indiegogo Campaign Fees

-$20,000: Composer Commission Fee* (includes copying expenses and travel for composer attend the performances)

*Artists deserve to be paid a good wage for their work. "Meet the Composer's" Commissioning Music: A Basic Guide suggests a commission fee between $13,000-$60,000 for a 10-25 minute work for full orchestra not including copying expenses and travel to premiere performances.

Funds already raised ($1,500)

-$1,500: $500 from each of the three orchestras that have already joined

Funds to raise ($20,500)

-$1,500: $500 from each additional New England orchestra

-$7,500: New Music USA Grant (pending)

-$1,500: Vermont Arts Council Grant (pending)

-$10,000: Indiegogo Campaign

Risks & Challenges

While I have never done a hike of this length, I have an athletic background and have done several shorter overnight hikes on the Appalachian Trail in the past.  In high school, I played Soccer, varsity Basketball, and was a league All-Star Tennis player.  I once cycled 100+ miles across Massachusetts and more recently played club Cricket in England.  In the past few months, I have been getting in shape with shorter hikes, treadmill runs, and researching gear, food, guidebooks, and other issues related with such a long hike.  I plan on hiking at least 10 miles per day which would mean finishing the hike in about 2.5 months, although I am giving myself 3 full months to do the hike to allow some buffer time in case something happens.

While I have certainly had my own doubts about completing such a long hike, during an overnight hike on the Appalachian Trail this past Summer I met a man in his 60's who was diabetic and had completed over three-quarters of the trail already.  If he can gather enough strength and determination to complete the trail, then certainly myself, a 28-year-old in good health and shape, has no excuses for not completing a 3rd of the trail.  Plus, I'm the kind of person who, when he is passionate about doing something, never even thinks about backing out of it.

If, however, for any reason the project is not completed, every effort will be made to return donations. 

In terms of composing, I have been a professional composer for the past five years and have been commissioned by other groups such as the Colorado State Music Teachers Association, the Northeastern State University Wind Ensemble (OK), the Arrowhead Union High School Wind Ensemble (WI), pianist Christopher Janwong McKiggan, saxophonist Allison Dromgold Adams, cellist Christine Thomas Tsen, and the Sounds of Stow Chorus and Orchestra for which we successfully ran a similar crowd-funding campaign to raise funds for the commission fee in 2012.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign with others who might be interested, via social media or word of mouth
  • Like Keane's Facebook Page and sign up for Keane's email newsletter for updates on the project and his other musical activities.
  • If I can get to a computer often enough, I will blogging during the hike, so follow along
  • If you live along the trail in New England and will be around this summer, I'd love to meet you when I pass through.  I'd also be very appreciative of any "Trail Magic" you could provide, like giving me a ride into town to buy supplies, letting me sleep on your couch for a night or take a hot shower. 

About the Composer

Keane Southard (b. 1987) is a composer and pianist who believes that music has the power to change how people think, feel, and act and that it can be a catalyst for positive change in the world.  Taken as a whole, his works reflect his many and diverse musical tastes, from medieval chant to 70's rock, Bach to the Blues, and German romanticism to Latin dance forms.  His compositions have been performed by ensembles such as the Cleveland Chamber Symphony, Longfellow Chorus and Orchestra, Berkeley Community Chorus and Orchestra, University of Colorado Wind Symphony, Juventas New Music Ensemble, Tesla Quartet, Playground Ensemble,  and the Ars Nova Singers. 


His music has been described as “highly-professional and well-orchestrated” (Portland Press Herald.)   Keane has been a recipient of many awards including the Lee Goldstein Composition Award from Baldwin-Wallace College, the Cecil Effinger Composition Award and George Lynn Prize from The University of Colorado-Boulder, First Prize in the Longfellow Chorus International Composers Cantata Competition, the Charles B. Olson Young Composer Award, and the Ars Nova Singers Colorado Composers Competition.  He has received commissions from the Colorado State Music Teachers Association, the Northeastern State University Wind Ensemble (OK), the Arrowhead Union High School Wind Ensemble (WI), the Sounds of Stow Chorus and Orchestra, pianist Christopher Janwong McKiggan, saxophonist Allison Dromgold Adams, and cellist Christine Thomas Tsen.  His compositions have been performed across the US and internationally in Germany, Brazil, Poland, the United Kingdom, Sweden, Romania, and Australia. He has been awarded residency fellowships at Playa and the Kimmel-Harding-Nelson Center and summer fellowships at the Bowdoin International Music Festival and Northeastern University Fusion Arts Exchange.  

Keane earned his M.M. in composition at the University of Colorado-Boulder where he served as a graduate assistant in music theory. He graduated Summa Cum Laude with his B.M. from the Conservatory at Baldwin-Wallace College in Berea, OH, where he double majored in music composition and music theory with a minor in English literature.  His primary composition teachers include Kenneth Girard, Loris Chobanian, Daniel Kellogg, Jeffrey Nytch, Carter Pann, Richard Toensing, and Allen Shawn, plus additional studies with Samuel Adler, Derek Bermel, Joao Guilherme Ripper, Brian Robison, and Hillary Zipper. An avid student of language and culture, Keane speaks Portuguese, Spanish, French, and Italian in addition to English.  He spent 2013 in Brazil as a Fulbright scholar doing research on music education and currently teaches at Bennington College in Vermont.

About the Orchestras

The Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra

With a dream that a world class musical organization could grow in the suburbs and support hundreds of professional musicians, Claflin Hill has created a venue for great music that serves residents of Worcester county and the surrounding region. Claflin Hill provides a practical option to residents of this region saving time, money and the aggravation of having to travel to the Boston or other urban settings.

About to launch its 16th season, Ron Della Chiesa, voice of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, stated “Through the high quality of performances and superb leadership, I can honestly say that this is one of the nation’s finest Regional Orchestras I have ever had the pleasure of hearing. . . How fortunate we are to have a group of musicians in a community orchestra so committed to playing great music with such passion and conviction for thousands of delighted patrons. The Claflin Hill Symphony stands as a testament to how important classical music is in our lives and how a group of musicians can have such a profound effect on everyone who hears them. ”

The Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra brings excellent live music to between 9,000 -12,000 community members in the Central Massachusetts area yearly. Free Family Night at the Bandstand concerts in downtown Milford are held every Tuesday, June – August, sponsored by local businesses. While a subjective concept, most people agree that opportunities to be involved with and attend arts and cultural events are crucial to a community’s quality of life.

Arts programs often spur community economic activity. On the evening of Claflin Hill Symphony concerts, most local Milford restaurants are filled to capacity both before and after the concert. Claflin Hill just received a Priscilla Mason Arts & Culture Award from ValleyCAST (Blackstone Valley Arts, Culture, Science Together) for cultural excellence. CHSO was recognized for significant contributions made to the Valley’s arts, culture and sciences in the past year.

The Wellesley Symphony Orchestra

Founded in 1948 as the Wellesley Community Orchestra, the Wellesley Symphony Orchestra was the brainchild of Wellesley residents: BSO violinist Rolland Tapley and Mrs. William Vogler. Maestro Tapley served as music director and conductor for nearly thirty years, offering three or four concerts each season, including a Pops Concert and a Youth Concert. Performances were held in various locations in Wellesley, Littleton and Framingham. Mr. Tapley retired in 1973 and was succeeded by Robert J. Prins (1972-1991) and Michael Webster (1992-1993). Max Hobart has been at the helm since 1993. Since 1984 the Wellesley Symphony Orchestra has been orchestra-in-residence at MassBay Community College.

The Wesleyan University Orchestra

The Wesleyan University Orchestra has been an integral part of the University’s Music Department for many years. The completion  of the Center for the Arts in 1973 allowed the orchestra to begin a regular annual series of concerts, and the 1980′s saw the rise of a strong orchestral program, first under Roger Solie, and then under Melvin Strauss.

1984 saw the premiere of Henry Brant’s  “Meteor Farm,” a commission which featured not only the orchestra, but also many of the Music Department’s celebrated World Music ensembles.  The 1988 “John Cage at Wesleyan” festival was a high-water mark for the orchestra; it featured a performance of Cage’s “Atlas Eclipticalis” with nearly a hundred performers, and distinguished guest performers including the Arditti Quartet.

Angel Gil-Ordóñez arrived as music director in the Fall of 1998, the orchestra and its members have played with many major artists under a program that brings performers from the CFA Concert Series together with Wesleyan students; among these perfomers have been Igor Kipnis, the Lydian String Quartet, Jaap Schroeder, and Pedro Carboné. Orchestral collaborations have included performances with Wesleyan’s Theater, Dance, and Film departments. The orchestra and theater department produced Tom Stoppard’s “Every Good Boy Deserves Favor” in the Spring of 2001, featuring music by André Previn; opera productions have included “The Countess III”, “Master Peter’s Puppet Show”, and “The Threepenny Opera”.

In Spring 2000, the orchestra initiated the “Millenium Concert”, which included collaborative commissioned works for the Jazz Orchestra and Gamelan, as well as premieres of works by Wesleyan composers. A year later, under the baton of guest conductor Zheng Xiao-ying, China’s first female conductor, the orchestra performed the U.S. premiere of Liu Yuan’s Symphony “Echo of Hakka Earth Buildings” as a part of the Chinese Music Festival “Echoes of the Earth”.  In 2005, as a benefit for the victims of Hurricane Katrina, two New Deal documentaries, the films “The Plow that Broke the Plains” and “The River”, were presented with live musical accompaniment by the orchestra, performing Virgil Thomson’s original scores. Another New Deal Documentary, “The City” (with a score by Aaron Copland), was presented with live music in the Fall of 2007. As a catalyst for contemporary music, the orchestra developed an annual Symphonic Workshop to showcase and premiere works by Wesleyan and other prominent U.S. composers, including Alvin Lucier, Anthony Braxton, Lawrence D. “Butch” Morris, Guilermo Gregorio, and David Amram.  Recent premieres include Mijidwewinan (“Messages”), by Barbara Croall, and Dear Mother Earth by Glenn McClure, both commissioned by the Wesleyan Center for the Arts as culminating events in its “Feet to the Fire” Festival, and for the inaugural year of the College of the Environment.

The Wesleyan Orchestra has also performed a variety of works such as Dvorak, Symphony no 8 in G Major; Holst,Jupiter from "The Planets"; Brahms, Variations on a Theme by Haydn; Handel, Water Music - Suite in D Major;Mendlessohn, Die Hebriden; and Beethoven, Symphony no. 7 in A Major.
story_txt:
Update: I'm excited to announce that a 4th orchestra is now on board the project as part of the consortium: The Sage City Symphony from Bennington, VT!  I'm thrilled to have them on board the project as the first orchestra from Vermont!
The Project
During the Summer of 2016, I will finally fulfill a lifelong dream of mine by hiking the New England portion of the Appalachian Trail, a journey of more than 700 miles (about one-third of the entire 2,200 mile trail.)  I grew up in Massachusetts and spent many weekends exploring the woods and wilderness of this region.  Then I will spend the next year realizing another long-held dream of mine, to write my first symphony for orchestra, which will be a 20-25 minute symphony inspired by the experiences hiking the trail, commissioned by a consortium of orchestras across New England for the 80th anniversary of the completion of the trail.  The work will be in five movements, one for each New England state the trail passes through (Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine) with the music for each arising from my experiences hiking in that particular state.  Professional, community, and collegiate orchestras from these five New England states will each premiere the work in their own communities during the 2017-18 season.  Orchestras already on board include the Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra (Milford, MA), the Wellesley Symphony Orchestra in (Wellesley, MA), and the Wesleyan University Orchestra in (Middletown, CT).  Several more orchestras are interested, and we expect these ensembles to join the consortium within the next year.We are also partnering with the Appalachian Trail Conservancy who is planning to have an orchestra from Maine perform the work as the main entertainment feature at their next Biennial Conference (August 4-10, 2017) at Colby College in Waterville, Maine, co-sponsored by the Appalachian Mountain Club and the Maine Appalachian Trail Club. 

Impact

But this project is more than just a realization of my own dreams and goals, and I am a firm believer that music can be a catalyst for positive change in the world.  Through these concerts throughout New England, associated educational events, and the publicity surrounding them, local orchestras will connect with the environmentalists and nature enthusiasts in their communities, a population that is not traditionally associated with classical music, in addition to their usual audiences. Likewise, this project will inspire and encourage classical music fans throughout the region to enjoy their local wilderness, including the Appalachian Trail, and to support local conservation efforts.
We invite you to be a part of the hike and donate to the project to help bring this musical celebration of the Appalachian Trail to life.  Every dollar helps!
Budget
Our goal is to raise at least half of the composer commission fee through this Indiegogo campaign.
Expenses ($22,000)
-$1,500: Estimated costs associated with doing the hike (including purchasing gear, fuel, food, and occasional lodging)
-$500: Indiegogo Campaign Fees
-$20,000: Composer Commission Fee* (includes copying expenses and travel for composer attend the performances)
*Artists deserve to be paid a good wage for their work. "Meet the Composer's" Commissioning Music: A Basic Guide suggests a commission fee between $13,000-$60,000 for a 10-25 minute work for full orchestra not including copying expenses and travel to premiere performances.
Funds already raised ($1,500)
-$1,500: $500 from each of the three orchestras that have already joined
Funds to raise ($20,500)
-$1,500: $500 from each additional New England orchestra
-$7,500: New Music USA Grant (pending)
-$1,500: Vermont Arts Council Grant (pending)
-$10,000: Indiegogo Campaign


Risks & Challenges
While I have never done a hike of this length, I have an athletic background and have done several shorter overnight hikes on the Appalachian Trail in the past.  In high school, I played Soccer, varsity Basketball, and was a league All-Star Tennis player.  I once cycled 100+ miles across Massachusetts and more recently played club Cricket in England.  In the past few months, I have been getting in shape with shorter hikes, treadmill runs, and researching gear, food, guidebooks, and other issues related with such a long hike.  I plan on hiking at least 10 miles per day which would mean finishing the hike in about 2.5 months, although I am giving myself 3 full months to do the hike to allow some buffer time in case something happens.
While I have certainly had my own doubts about completing such a long hike, during an overnight hike on the Appalachian Trail this past Summer I met a man in his 60's who was diabetic and had completed over three-quarters of the trail already.  If he can gather enough strength and determination to complete the trail, then certainly myself, a 28-year-old in good health and shape, has no excuses for not completing a 3rd of the trail.  Plus, I'm the kind of person who, when he is passionate about doing something, never even thinks about backing out of it.
If, however, for any reason the project is not completed, every effort will be made to return donations. In terms of composing, I have been a professional composer for the past five years and have been commissioned by other groups such as the Colorado State Music Teachers Association, the Northeastern State University Wind Ensemble (OK), the Arrowhead Union High School Wind Ensemble (WI), pianist Christopher Janwong McKiggan, saxophonist Allison Dromgold Adams, cellist Christine Thomas Tsen, and the Sounds of Stow Chorus and Orchestra for which we successfully ran a similar crowd-funding campaign to raise funds for the commission fee in 2012.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with others who might be interested, via social media or word of mouth
Like Keane's Facebook Page and sign up for Keane's email newsletter for updates on the project and his other musical activities.
If I can get to a computer often enough, I will blogging during the hike, so follow along
If you live along the trail in New England and will be around this summer, I'd love to meet you when I pass through.  I'd also be very appreciative of any "Trail Magic" you could provide, like giving me a ride into town to buy supplies, letting me sleep on your couch for a night or take a hot shower. 


About the Composer
Keane Southard (b. 1987) is a composer and pianist who believes that music has the power to change how people think, feel, and act and that it can be a catalyst for positive change in the world.  Taken as a whole, his works reflect his many and diverse musical tastes, from medieval chant to 70's rock, Bach to the Blues, and German romanticism to Latin dance forms.  His compositions have been performed by ensembles such as the Cleveland Chamber Symphony, Longfellow Chorus and Orchestra, Berkeley Community Chorus and Orchestra, University of Colorado Wind Symphony, Juventas New Music Ensemble, Tesla Quartet, Playground Ensemble,  and the Ars Nova Singers. His music has been described as “highly-professional and well-orchestrated” (Portland Press Herald.)   Keane has been a recipient of many awards including the Lee Goldstein Composition Award from Baldwin-Wallace College, the Cecil Effinger Composition Award and George Lynn Prize from The University of Colorado-Boulder, First Prize in the Longfellow Chorus International Composers Cantata Competition, the Charles B. Olson Young Composer Award, and the Ars Nova Singers Colorado Composers Competition.  He has received commissions from the Colorado State Music Teachers Association, the Northeastern State University Wind Ensemble (OK), the Arrowhead Union High School Wind Ensemble (WI), the Sounds of Stow Chorus and Orchestra, pianist Christopher Janwong McKiggan, saxophonist Allison Dromgold Adams, and cellist Christine Thomas Tsen.  His compositions have been performed across the US and internationally in Germany, Brazil, Poland, the United Kingdom, Sweden, Romania, and Australia. He has been awarded residency fellowships at Playa and the Kimmel-Harding-Nelson Center and summer fellowships at the Bowdoin International Music Festival and Northeastern University Fusion Arts Exchange.  Keane earned his M.M. in composition at the University of Colorado-Boulder where he served as a graduate assistant in music theory. He graduated Summa Cum Laude with his B.M. from the Conservatory at Baldwin-Wallace College in Berea, OH, where he double majored in music composition and music theory with a minor in English literature.  His primary composition teachers include Kenneth Girard, Loris Chobanian, Daniel Kellogg, Jeffrey Nytch, Carter Pann, Richard Toensing, and Allen Shawn, plus additional studies with Samuel Adler, Derek Bermel, Joao Guilherme Ripper, Brian Robison, and Hillary Zipper. An avid student of language and culture, Keane speaks Portuguese, Spanish, French, and Italian in addition to English.  He spent 2013 in Brazil as a Fulbright scholar doing research on music education and currently teaches at Bennington College in Vermont.

About the Orchestras

The Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra


With a dream that a world class musical organization could grow in the suburbs and support hundreds of professional musicians, Claflin Hill has created a venue for great music that serves residents of Worcester county and the surrounding region. Claflin Hill provides a practical option to residents of this region saving time, money and the aggravation of having to travel to the Boston or other urban settings.
About to launch its 16th season, Ron Della Chiesa, voice of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, stated “Through the high quality of performances and superb leadership, I can honestly say that this is one of the nation’s finest Regional Orchestras I have ever had the pleasure of hearing. . . How fortunate we are to have a group of musicians in a community orchestra so committed to playing great music with such passion and conviction for thousands of delighted patrons. The Claflin Hill Symphony stands as a testament to how important classical music is in our lives and how a group of musicians can have such a profound effect on everyone who hears them. ”
The Claflin Hill Symphony Orchestra brings excellent live music to between 9,000 -12,000 community members in the Central Massachusetts area yearly. Free Family Night at the Bandstand concerts in downtown Milford are held every Tuesday, June – August, sponsored by local businesses. While a subjective concept, most people agree that opportunities to be involved with and attend arts and cultural events are crucial to a community’s quality of life.

Claflin Hill just received a Priscilla Mason Arts & Culture Award from ValleyCAST (Blackstone Valley Arts, Culture, Science Together) for cultural excellence. CHSO was recognized for significant contributions made to the Valley’s arts, culture and sciences in the past year.

Maestro Tapley served as music director and conductor for nearly thirty years, offering three or four concerts each season, including a Pops Concert and a Youth Concert. Performances were held in various locations in Wellesley, Littleton and Framingham. Mr. Tapley retired in 1973 and was succeeded by Robert J. Prins (1972-1991) and Michael Webster (1992-1993). Max Hobart has been at the helm since 1993. Since 1984 the Wellesley Symphony Orchestra has been orchestra-in-residence at MassBay Community College.
The Wesleyan University Orchestra

Orchestral collaborations have included performances with Wesleyan’s Theater, Dance, and Film departments. The orchestra and theater department produced Tom Stoppard’s “Every Good Boy Deserves Favor” in the Spring of 2001, featuring music by André Previn; opera productions have included “The Countess III”, “Master Peter’s Puppet Show”, and “The Threepenny Opera”.

A year later, under the baton of guest conductor Zheng Xiao-ying, China’s first female conductor, the orchestra performed the U.S. premiere of Liu Yuan’s Symphony “Echo of Hakka Earth Buildings” as a part of the Chinese Music Festival “Echoes of the Earth”.  In 2005, as a benefit for the victims of Hurricane Katrina, two New Deal documentaries, the films “The Plow that Broke the Plains” and “The River”, were presented with live musical accompaniment by the orchestra, performing Virgil Thomson’s original scores. The Wesleyan Orchestra has also performed a variety of works such as Dvorak, Symphony no 8 in G Major; Holst,Jupiter from "The Planets"; Brahms, Variations on a Theme by Haydn; Handel, Water Music - Suite in D Major;Mendlessohn, Die Hebriden; and Beethoven, Symphony no. 7 in A Major.

story:
Songs from the eye of the storm…

8 years ago I saw a friend playfully plucking a ukulele and thought, 4 strings…I can do that! I thought I would just play around at home. The playing quickly evolved into intricate re-arranging of songs, writing my own songs, picking up other instruments and playing amazing NYC venues over the next few years as my identity as a musician was born.

Armed with solid songs, I connected with a producer and started working on my debut album. Heartbreakingly, I was mislead with the producer, lost thousands of my own dollars and over a year of work, and left with no finished product.

But now I’m back and ready to complete this creative journey. I’m partnering with a wonderful new producer and ready to share with you the songs I have been creating over the past few years.

To fully realize these songs as I envision them, I have assembled an incredible team of musicians, creators and collaborators. These components, along with the recording studio, mixing and mastering of the album, design elements and all the other curated moments that go into this process, are expensive. At this point I’ve spent as much of my personal money as I possibly can, and I have hit a wall. 

So I am asking for help. Help from my greater community of listeners, co-conspirators, believers. Help from you.

It’s time to bring these songs from the live experience into the other. Into the personal experience. To be shared, repeated, and enjoyed outside of the single staged moment.

These songs are written from a maelstrom of chaos and desperation while being anchored in hope and joy. I believe in the beauty and the truth of these songs. And I know you will too.

Will you partner with me?

story:
Hannah Vandie is a 17 year old country-pop singer-songwriter from Maben, Mississippi.  She started singing and songwriting at a young age having been inspired by the music of Carrie Underwood.  Hannah has recorded a number of cover songs as well as several original tracks.  To find out more about Hannah and to listen to some of her music visit her website.

Hannah is now ready to take her music career to the next stage and is looking to release her 4 track debut EP.  She has already recorded 3 of the 4 tracks and is looking for funding to finish the project which will cost around $750.

One of the tracks on the debut EP is called Dark Horses, a track which Hannah co-wrote.  Dark Horses contains an underlying anti-bullying message and Hannah plans to travel to the UK in October to record a video for this song allowing her to work with a range of music industry professionals.  The cost of making the video is around $2,250.

All support, however large or small, is greatly appreciated and there are a selection of 'perks' available to say thank you for your support.  To view Hannah's first music video 'Joe Jack' click on the Gallery tab at the top of the page.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Northern Spies need your help!  

After spending over a year honing an original repertoire of rootsy power pop material, the time has come for Northern Spies to commit these songs to tape.  We are asking for your help in funding this endeavor.  Recording a full length album is no cheap matter without a label, and we figure that $2500 will help us accomplish the task without having to take out second mortgages on our homes or starve for a few months.  We have worked very hard to bring these songs to life, and are very proud of how far we've come with them - help us capture our work for posterity!

What's in it for you?

Contributing to Northern Spies' as-yet-untitled album has some extra special perks for you.  Do you like limited edition artwork?  New t-shirts?  Homemade apple pie?  Seeing your name in lights (or at least album liner notes)?  Then there's no reason why you shouldn't contribute to Northern Spies' Indiegogo campaign!

More about Northern Spies: 

It all started deep in the frosty majesty of Rochester, NY's winter landscape.  Long-time pals and former bandmates Jeremy O’Reilly and Alex Northrup began working on some of Northrup’s tunes on their acoustic guitars in the winter of ’14, and decided it was time to find a drummer. After playing together in a one-off Fleetwood Mac cover project and bonding over a mutual admiration of The Band, Travis Johansen soon joined on drums. Adding high-energy Bonham-esque drums, Johansen kicked these previously tame tunes up a notch. With the mix of crashing drums and jangling guitar, the guys rounded out their cast with the Craigslist discovery of AJ Schneeberg, a recent transplant from New Jersey. Synergizing the rhythm section, Schneeberg’s buttery sweet bass lines rock and lock into the groove epitomizing the Northern Spies’ sound.

With this in place, Northern Spies’ updated take on classic power pop and roots rock comes as a worthy addition to the Rochester, NY music scene. 2014’s Nothing But Static EP has garnered them regional airplay, and the upcoming February 2016 release of the single “Do” is set to follow. Blending surfy guitar licks and coded lyrics the Spies appeal to an indie crowd, though their love of bluesy jams, familiar classics, and no-nonsense toe-tapping beats have been winning them a wider audience across western NY. Buffalo’s premier indie music blog Buffablog sates that their sound “recalls acts like Elvis Costello, the Byrds, REM, and Stephen Malkmus.”

Not one to rest on their laurels, the band decided it was time to put their mass of tunes to tape in the format of a full length album. After a successful run recording their soon-to-be released single, "Do," there was no question as to whether or not the Spies would return to 1809 Studios to record their album with Dave Drago. Capturing the spirit of the band, Drago helped to provide further insight to the songs, proving to be one of the best recording collaborations the band has experienced. The yet-to-be-titled album promises to be an engaging statement, and one true to the live four-man sound the band has honed.

With this in place, Northern Spies’ updated take on classic power pop and roots rock comes as a worthy addition to the Rochester, NY music scene. 2014’s Nothing But Static EP has garnered them regional airplay, and the upcoming February 2016 release of the single “Do” is set to follow. Blending surfy guitar licks and coded lyrics the Spies appeal to an indie crowd, though their love of bluesy jams, familiar classics, and no-nonsense toe-tapping beats have been winning them a wider audience across western NY. Buffalo’s premier indie music blog Buffablog sates that their sound “recalls acts like Elvis Costello, the Byrds, REM, and Stephen Malkmus.”
Not one to rest on their laurels, the band decided it was time to put their mass of tunes to tape in the format of a full length album. After a successful run recording their soon-to-be released single, "Do," there was no question as to whether or not the Spies would return to 1809 Studios to record their album with Dave Drago. Capturing the spirit of the band, Drago helped to provide further insight to the songs, proving to be one of the best recording collaborations the band has experienced. The yet-to-be-titled album promises to be an engaging statement, and one true to the live four-man sound the band has honed.

story:
Our Insane Journey Thus Far:

We are Born for War, a metal band comprised of 4 Marines, one of whom is still Active Duty, out of Hollywood, CA. Our story has been something kind of like what you would see in a movie.

We all came together a little over a year ago when our lead guitarist, Tommie, met Mark at their first class at the same college. She noticed his Marine Corps desert camouflage pants that he cut into shorts, he happened to sit right next to her and they struck up a conversation about the Marine Corps right away. They both had a goal when they moved to Hollywood, and that was to create one hell of a metal band and to make it our career. So they both ended up jamming together and started the beginnings of Born for War basically in the same day. TK, our drummer, was also going to the same college and we were introduced to him through an all military band in the area called Kings of Carnage. They also helped us get in contact with Sam, our vocalist; who is currently active duty in the Marine Corps on Camp Pendleton, and we all ended up meeting him at Knotfest 2014.

We quickly began writing and ended up creating the most amazing music that any of us had ever created before! Unfortunately, Sam was called away on deployment before we could play any shows, but the story doesn't end there. Despite his absence, we diligently worked on our material and practiced nearly every day until he returned. As luck would have it, that Sam was unexpectedly able to come home early from his deployment! We immediately began working on booking shows and we came across an amazing opportunity, the Battle for Knotfest 2015. Most bands would never think about having a battle for their first show, but us being the "living on the edge" Marines that we are, we signed up for it. The show ended up being phenomenal, despite having gear issues throughout, and we Won! Before we knew it, we were on stage in front of a massive crowd at Knotfest 2015, the same place we met Sam only a year before, and people were going insane!

Once that happened, tons of shows started rolling our way, and even our first sponsorship, Coldcock Whiskey. But then we realized, we need an album. So many people have been asking us for it, so here we are. Despite having a sponsorship, we are having difficulties funding our album on our own. So, we are asking for a miracle again, but this time, we want to make this an experience for all who donate to us for this album. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently in the studio recording the album, but we need your help to finish it, so we are asking to help us raise $3,500 in order to finish what we started. So what's in it for you?

The more you donate to our album, the more you get! Depending on how much you donate, you can receive anything from a Digital Pre-Order to being in one of our Music Videos! And because we want to make this an experience for the fans, you will get exclusive video footage of us in the studio and more.

Risks & Challenges

The obvious risk is that we won't be able to raise the funds we need, if that occurs, all the proceeds that was received will still go towards the album, and we would get a loan in order to finish it. If we need overtime, it will be paid for by ourselves, so really there aren't many risks involved with helping us finish our album.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but can't contribute, that's fine! Share us with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, whatever you use in order to get the word out about us. If you aren't sure if you should support this band, check out our live videos on our website at www.born-for-war.com and see for yourself.

story: Thank you for your support!

story:
This summer...

Regents Opera has performed large-scale operas to critical acclaim all over England since 2012, and this summer we are delighted to present La Boheme at X[BP1]  venues across the country. On Tuesday 24th May, our La Boheme will come to London.  We need your help to make this performance truly special – the others will feature small instrumental ensemble and piano, but we hope to hire an 11-piece orchestra to celebrate the debut of this summer tour.


Why do we need an orchestra?

Regents Opera is proud to offer the highest quality of work, and an 11-piece orchestra will ensure that our production is as faithful to Puccini’s original score as possible.

A professional orchestra will provide the dramatic platform on which our talented singers can shine even more brilliantly, giving the evening a deeper colour and fully rounding out your experience of this beloved opera.We need your help to make this possible! Please consider supporting Regents Opera’s production of La Boheme.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our campaign, you can still support Regents Opera:

-  Send this campaign to your friends www.igg.me/at/regentslaboheme

-  Buy tickets to the show.https://www.ticketsource.co.uk/regentsopera

story:
Get ready folks to get off your darn caboose and trot across the waxed dance floor, hoofing your feets', doing the Skoodle um Skoo! 

We are thrilled for you to hear our double release record & vinyl, we've never been so excited & fulfilled by a recording before! 

 We've recorded our CD & VINYL on an 8 track using 1/2 IN tape and we are so deeply proud of this humdinger! 

We want to share this record with everyone and get ya'll out to the ginmills stomping your worn out boots and sharing your briar tobacco pipes!
Though in order to do this we need you!
We have racked up a grand total of $5200 in costs (not including whiskey!) and as much trotting around we do to every flea & farmer market you can name we aren't making enough to fund our most important project to date! We've spent our nickles, dimes, silver & gold and even threw in a pearl ring and pocket watch to cover the costs below, but still are short!
This is where our copper is going to:
Recording Studio (Having the best recording equipment and ribbon mics,)
1/2 IN tape reels
Mixing & mastering,
Sit in piano musician,
Copyright registration,
Artwork, graphics, photography & layouts, 
Pressing & printing of vinyl,
Marketing & PR,
Tour outreach fund- (This allows us to play at Retirement homes, legions, and schools that cannot afford our fee.)
All of our crazy MERCH! Including:
Our new record!
Our new vinyl!
Our home made patches,
Our home made, hand stitched, tea stained postcards,
Our buttons,
Our stickers,
Our home made silk screened T shirts,
Our home brewed LIBIDO TEA,
Our voodoo beads,
  ALONE, we would create a wonderful record that we were so proud of but with you  we can have more than 1 copy and share it with as many folks that care to get up to dance The Lindy Hop! With your support we are able to make this our best record and our very FIRST vinyl! With your generosity we want to reward you with the tokens from the past of the 1920's and show you how much we appreciate you!

For this record, "Bringing Satan Down," and our 7 inch vinyl, "Dan the Shoe Shine Man," to be pressed would not only give us what we need for the next step of our professional musical careers, it would also give an incredibly sentimental notion its life. 

Recently, Norah's grandmother passed away, (she is the woman on the front cover,) and she was the #1 fan of The Vaudevillian.
She raised Norah in her trailer park, and was with Norah when they met Brendan on the shore of Port Elgin. That day, she told Norah she thought she would one day marry Brendan... 
Grandma loved The Vaudevillian's tunes and she would dance to 'em with a wild look in her eye, singing along to some of the more naughty ones, though lo & behold she was a very religious woman. The 1st track on this record; "Bringing Satan Down" is called "Broom Shooter" which tells the story of when Norah was a 3 year old girl and her daddy tried to kidnap her... but grandma got the shotgun out and held him off. When the police man showed up she told him it was merely a broom... 
To bring this album to life would be to bring Grandmas story to life, and we believe fully well that wherever she is she will be trotting & hoofing her feets', causing quite the ruckus!    

 We appreciate all ya'lls support so incredibly much! This record & vinyl mean the world to us and hold a very special spot in our hearts and value you so much. Please share this campaign and our pages, and come on out and share a dance with us at our next show! Remember to shine your shoes for it though or get Brendan to shine your hoofers for ye!
